resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

issuetype.description: An improvement or enhancement to an existing feature or task.
issuetype.name: Improvement

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

jorisvandenbossche commented on pull request #6410: ARROW-5757: [Python] Remove Python 2.7 support
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/6410#discussion_r378247096
 
 

 ##########
 File path: python/pyarrow/types.pxi
 ##########
 @@ -2157,7 +2151,7 @@ cdef DataType ensure_type(object ty, c_bool allow_none=False):
         return None
     elif isinstance(ty, DataType):
         return ty
-    elif isinstance(ty, six.string_types):
+    elif isinstance(ty, str):
 
 Review comment:
   here, string_types is replaces with only `str`, but just above (in the diff), it is replaced with `(bytes, str)`. Is there a reason for the difference?
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the

users@infra.apache.org

issuetype.description: A task that needs to be done.
issuetype.name: Task

fields.description:
By the end of 2019 many scientific Python projects will stop supporting Python 2 altogether:
https://python3statement.org/

We'll certainly support Python 2 in Arrow 1.0 but we could perhaps drop support in 1.1.

comments.body: Note: pandas 0.25.0 was just released without Python 2.7 support
Release 1.0 with Python 2 support and then drop immediately?

Some discussion happened in ARROW-7555 (which I just closed as a duplicate).

Now that 1.0 has been postponed a bit and we are first doing a 0.16 release, we should consider dropping python 2.7 support after 0.16 already, since python 2.7 is no longer maintained (and eg numpy and pandas also already dropped support).

Wes:

 {quote}We probably need to discuss this on the mailing list. Sadly Python 2.7 is still the most popular Python version according to pypistats.org

https://pypistats.org/packages/pyarrow
{quote}

With conda, on the other hand, Python 2.7 is only 5% of the downloads (but, conda downloads are much smaller in number than the PyPI ones. I checked Dec 2019, which had 137,845 downloads on conda, which is kind the daily number on PyPI).
I'm also +1 for dropping after 0.16.0. We aren't doing ourselves or the users any favors by continuing 2.7 support.
